verses.verse: There is <S%H3426><s%> an evil <S%H7451><s%> which I have seen <S%H7200><s%> under the sun, <S%H8121><s%> and it is heavy <S%H7227><s%> on men: <S%H120><s%>

a man <S%H376><s%> to whom God <S%H430><s%> gives <S%H5414><s%> riches, <S%H6239><s%> wealth, <S%H6239><s%> and honor, <S%H3519><s%> so that he lacks <S%H2638><s%> nothing for his soul <S%H5315><s%> of all that he desires, <S%H183><s%> yet God <S%H430><s%> gives him no power <S%H7980><s%> to eat <S%H398><s%> of it, <S%H376><s%> but an alien eats <S%H398><s%> it. <S%H1892><s%> This is vanity, and it is an evil <S%H7451><s%> disease. <S%H2483><s%>

If a man <S%H376><s%> fathers <S%H3205><s%> a hundred <S%H3967><s%> children, <S%H2421><s%> and lives many <S%H7227><s%> years, <S%H8141><s%> so that the days <S%H3117><s%> of his years <S%H8141><s%> are many, <S%H7227><s%> but his soul <S%H5315><s%> is not filled <S%H7646><s%> with good, <S%H2896><s%> and moreover he has no burial; <S%H6900><s%> I say, <S%H559><s%> that a stillborn <S%H5309><s%> child is better than he: <S%H2896><s%>
for it comes <S%H935><s%> in vanity, <S%H1892><s%> and departs <S%H3212><s%> in darkness, <S%H2822><s%> and its name <S%H8034><s%> is covered <S%H3680><s%> with darkness. <S%H2822><s%>
Moreover it has not seen <S%H7200><s%> the sun <S%H8121><s%> nor known <S%H3045><s%> it. <S%H2088><s%> This has rest <S%H5183><s%> rather than the other. <S%H2088><s%>

Yes, <S%H432><s%> though he live <S%H2421><s%> a thousand <S%H505><s%> years <S%H8141><s%> twice <S%H6471><s%> told, <S%H7200><s%> and yet fails to enjoy good, <S%H2896><s%> don't <S%H1980><s%> all go to one <S%H259><s%> place? <S%H4725><s%>
All the labor <S%H5999><s%> of man <S%H120><s%> is for his mouth, <S%H6310><s%> and yet the appetite <S%H5315><s%> is not filled. <S%H4390><s%>

For what advantage has the wise <S%H2450><s%> more <S%H3148><s%> than the fool? <S%H3684><s%> What has the poor <S%H6041><s%> man, <S%H3045><s%> that knows how to walk <S%H1980><s%> before the living? <S%H2416><s%>

Better <S%H2896><s%> is the sight <S%H4758><s%> of the eyes <S%H5869><s%> than the wandering <S%H1980><s%> of the desire. <S%H5315><s%> This also is vanity <S%H1892><s%> and a chasing <S%H7469><s%> after wind. <S%H7307><s%>

Whatever has been, <S%H7121><s%> its name was given long ago; <S%H3528><s%> and it is known <S%H3045><s%> what man <S%H120><s%> is; <S%H3201><s%> neither can he contend <S%H1777><s%> with him who is mightier than he. <S%H8623><s%>
For there are <S%H3426><s%> many <S%H7235><s%> words <S%H1697><s%> that create <S%H7235><s%> vanity. <S%H1892><s%> What does that profit <S%H3148><s%> man? <S%H120><s%>

For who knows <S%H3045><s%> what is good <S%H2896><s%> for man <S%H120><s%> in life, <S%H2416><s%> all <S%H4557><s%> the days <S%H3117><s%> of his vain <S%H1892><s%> life <S%H2416><s%> which he spends <S%H6213><s%> like a shadow? <S%H6738><s%> For who can tell <S%H5046><s%> a man <S%H120><s%> what will be after <S%H310><s%> him under the sun? <S%H8121><s%>
